questions.text: Which of the following is not developed from the hindgut?
questions.solution:
Gut is endodermal in origin and is derived from the yolk sac. The developing gut is divided into three segments -

Foregut

  • The artery of foregut is the coeliac trunk.
  • Foregut derivatives of GIT are esophagus, stomach, duodenum (upto opening of main pancreatic duct), liver and pancreas.

Midgut

  • The artery of midgut is the superior mesenteric artery.
  • A GIT derivatives of midgut are duodenum (distal to opening of main pancreatic duct), small intestine (jejunum, ileum), appendix, cecum, ascending colon and proximal (right) 2/3 of transverse colon.

Hindgut

  • The artery of hindgut is the inferior mesenteric artery.
  • Hindgut derivatives are distal (left) 1/3 of transverse colon, descending colon, proximal part of rectumEED a Caudal part of hind gut is called cloaca.
  • Distal part of rectum and upper part of the canal are developed from endodermal cloaca.

Reference: Clinical Embryology by Vishram Singh second edition, Chapter the abdomen

questions.text: The seeds of sweet pea, that are widely consumed during famines, contain which of the following osteo lathyrogens?
questions.solution:
• The seeds of the 'sweet pea,' a Lathyrus legume that is widely consumed during famines, contain the osteolathyrogen g-glutamyl-β-aminopropionitrile (BAPN), a glutamine derivative of β-aminopropionitrile.
  • The seeds of certain Lathyrus species also contain α,g-diaminobutyric acid, an analog of ornithine, that inhibits the hepatic urea cycle enzyme ornithine
  • The resulting disruption of the urea cycle leads to ammonia toxicity. Finally, l-β-methylamino alanine, a neurotoxic amino acid present in Cycad seeds, implicated as a risk factor for neurodegenerative diseases including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis-Parkinson dementia complex in natives of Guam who consume either fruit bats that feed on cycad fruit, or flour made from cycad seeds.

Reference: Harper 30/ e, page 19-20.

questions.text: A neonate is born with the anomaly shown below. The pediatrician should be suspecting which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This is Holoprosencephaly which is seen in Patau syndrome



Reference: Nelson's textbook of Paediatrics twenty first edition, Page 778

questions.text: Maple Urine Syrup Disease type 3 can result from mutations in the genes that encode -
questions.solution:
Metabolic disorders of branched chain amino acids catabolism -

  • As the name implies, the odor of urine in maple syrup urine disease (branched-chain ketonuria, or MSUD) suggests maple syrup, or burnt sugar.
  • The biochemical defect in MSUD involves the α-keto acid decarboxylase complex.
  • Plasma and urinary levels of leucine, isoleucine, valine, and their α-keto acids and α-hydroxy acids (reduced α-keto acids) are elevated, but the urinary keto acids derived principally from leucine.
  • Signs and symptoms of MSUD include often fatal ketoacidosis, neurological derangements, mental retardation, and a maple syrup odor of urine.
  • The mechanism of toxicity is unknown. Early diagnosis by enzymatic analysis is essential to avoid brain damage and early mortality by replacing dietary protein by an amino acid mixture that lacks leucine, isoleucine, and valine.
  • The molecular genetics of MSUD are heterogeneous. MSUD can result from mutations in the genes that encode E1α, E1β, E2, and E3.
  • Based on the locus affected, genetic subtypes of MSUD are recognized.
    • Type IA MSUD arises from mutations in the E1α gene
    • Type IB in the E1β gene
    • Type II in the E2 gene
    • Type III in the E3 gene.
  • In intermittent branched-chain ketonuria, the α-keto acid decarboxylase retains some activity, and symptoms occur later in life.
  • In isovaleric acidemia, ingestion of protein-rich foods elevates isovalerate, the deacylation product of isovaleryl-CoA.

The impaired enzyme in isovaleric acidemia is isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase. Vomiting, acidosis, and coma follow ingestion of excess protein. Accumulated isovaleryl-CoA is hydrolyzed to isovalerate and excreted.

Reference: Harper 30/ e, page 309-310

Allantoic is associated with Early blood formation and Bladder development

Arachidonic acid contains no double bonds

questions.text: The Nucleus of the tractus solitarius of the facial nerve is concerned with which of the following components?

The fibers of the nerve are connected to four nuclei situated in the lower pons.

  • Superior salivatory nucleus or parasympathetic - General visceral efferent
  • Lacrimatory nucleus is also parasympathetic - General visceral afferent

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids does not contain a chiral carbon?
questions.solution:
With the sole exception of glycine, the α-carbon of every amino acid is chiral. Although some protein amino acids are dextrorotatory and some levorotatory, all share the absolute configuration of L-glyceraldehyde and thus are defined as L-α-amino acids.

Glycine is the only optically inactive amino acid.

Reference: Harper 30/ e, page 19

questions.text: Cisterna pontis contains which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Cisterna pontis:

  • It is present on the ventral aspect of pons. It is continuous with interpeduncular cistern cranially, with cerebellomedullary cistern behind and with spinal subarachnoid space caudally.
  • It contains:
    • The basilar artery and the origin of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA)
    • The origin of the superior cerebellar arteries
    • The sixth (VI) cranial nerve

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 4, 8th Edition, Page No - 29

questions.text: Which type of RNA has the highest percentage of modified bases?
questions.solution:
Transfer RNA (tRNA)

  • RNA which transfers amino acid from the cytoplasm to the ribosomal protein synthesizing machinery.
  • Clover leaf shape in the secondary structure. L-shaped tertiary structure.
  • Single tRNA contains 74-95 nucleotides
  • Cytoplasmic translation systems possess 31 tRNA species. Mitochondrial systems possess 22 tRNAs.
  • Transfer RNA is extensively processed and modified.
  • The tRNA molecules serve as adapter molecules for the translation of mRNA into protein sequences.
  • The tRNAs contain many modifications of the standard bases A, U, G, and C, including methylation, reduction, deamination, and rearranged glycosidic bonds. Further posttranscriptional modification of the tRNA molecules includes nucleotide alkylations.

Reference: Harper 30e page 411

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: Anterior layer of the carotid sheath is derived from -
questions.solution:
Carotid sheath -

  • It is a condensation of the fibroareolar tissue around the main vessels of the neck.
  • Formation: It is formed on the anterior aspect by pre tracheal fascia and on the posterior aspect by prevertebral fascia.
  • Contents: The contents are the common or internal carotid arteries, the internal jugular vein and the vagus nerve. It is thin over the vein.
  • In the upper part of the sheath, there are IX, XI, XII nerves also. These nerves pierce the sheet at different points.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 3, 8th Edition, Page No - 90

Computer database with all gene knowledge
Collection of gene copies of one organism as completely as possible in bits and pieces

questions.text: True statement about gene library -
questions.solution:
Gene Library

A collection of recombinant DNA clones generated from a specific source.

There are two types of Gene Library:

  • Genomic DNA library:
    • Prepared from total genomic DNA of an organism. By digestion of Genomic DNA by Restriction Endonuclease.
    • Then recombinant clones of such digested DNA are produced by recombinant DNA technology.
  • cDNA library
    • cDNA is prepared from mRNA by the action of Reverse Transcriptase
    • The recombinant clones for cDNA are produced by Recombinant DNA Technology.
  • Advantages of cDNA over Genomic DNA
    • Contains only coding sequences.
    • Represent the mRNA in a tissue.
    • Hence, used to study gene expression.

Reference: Harper 30e page 455.

questions.text: All of the following bones are unpaired, except -
questions.solution:
The calvaria or braincase is composed of 14 bones including three paired ear ossicles.



The facial skeleton is composed of 14 bones.

questions.text: Trypsin cleaves -
questions.solution:
Serine proteases differ in substrate specificity -

  • Trypsin cleaves basic amino acids like Arginine, Lysine
  • Chymotrypsin cleaves hydrophobic bulky amino acids like Tryptophan, Tyrosine, Phenylalanine
  • Elastase cleaves small neutral amino acids like Alanine, Glycine

Reference: Harper 30/ e, page 539

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of origin of the testicular artery?
questions.solution:
The testicular artery:

  • It is a branch of the abdominal aorta given off at the level of vertebra L2.
  • It descends on the posterior abdominal wall to reach the deep inguinal ring where it enters the spermatic cord.
  • At the posterior border of the testis, it divides into branches.
  • Some small branches enter the posterior border, while larger branches, medial and lateral, pierce the tunica albuginea and run on the surface of the testis to ramify in the tunica vasculosa.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page No - 264

questions.text: CRISPR-Cas9 has revolutionized genomic DNA studies. Which of the following is true for CRISPR-Cas9?
questions.solution:
Option A: CRISPR-Cas9 is a novel Gene editing or gene regulatory technique.

Option B & Option C: CRISPR-Cas9 is a RNA-directed site specific endonuclease.

Cas9 is CRISPR associated protein 9, has an endonuclease enzyme activity which used CRISPR sequences as a guide. Then recognizes specific DNA strands that are complementary to CRISPR sequence & cleave them.

CRISPR - Cas9 (clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats - CRISPR associated gene/protein 9)

CRISPR

  • It is a novel Gene editing or gene regulatory technique.
  • CRISPR is found in the genomes of prokaryotic organisms.
  • It found in approximately 50% of sequenced bacterial genomes and 90% of sequenced archaea.
  • These sequences are originally derived from DNA fragments of bacteriophages that had previously infected the prokaryote. Later they are used by prokaryotes to detect and destroy DNA from similar bacteriophages during subsequent infections to prokaryotes.
  • So these sequences play role as an antiviral (antiphase) defense system for prokaryotes and provide an acquired or adaptive immunity to prevent reinfection of a bacterium by specific bacteriophages
  • CRISPR complements the system of restriction endonucleases and methylases. CRISPR uses RNA-based targeting to bring the Cas9 nuclease to foreign (or any complementary) DNA.

CAS9

  • An endonuclease enzyme
  • It uses CRISPR sequences as a guide (as guide RNA). Then recognizes specific DNA strands that are complementary to CRISPR sequence & cleave them.
  • Both together are used to edit genes within organisms. Within bacteria this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA.
  • The CRISPR system has been also adapted for use in eukaryotic cells, including human cells, where it has been shown to be an RNA-directed site-specific nuclease just as it is in bacteria.
  • It has wide varieties of application in medicine, in basic biological research, food and farming industries.
  • In medicine, it was used to experimentally to treat a patient with a genetic disorder (eg sickle cell disease), to treat viral infection like HIV etc.
  • Variations on the use of CRISPR allow for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and even modulation of gene transcription in basic biological research.
  • Thus, CRISPR has added an exciting new, highly efficient, and very specific technology to the toolbox of methods for the manipulation of DNA and genetic analysis of mammalian cells.
  • A variant of the CRISPR-Cas system, C2c2, has been shown to site-specifically cleave RNA. This exciting discovery paves the way for potential specific alteration of mRNA levels in human cells.


Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 39 PN 435

questions.text: What is the root value of the inferior gluteal nerve?
questions.solution:
Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2):

  • Inferior gluteal nerve is a branch of the sacral plexus given off in the pelvis.
  • It enters the gluteal region through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis.
  • It ends by supplying the gluteus maximus only, to which it is fully committed.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page No - 82

questions.text: A patient has a blood pH of 7.25 and a bicarbonate concentration of 20 mmol/L. If the renal tubules secrete 200 mmol of hydrogen ions per day, what is the net acid excretion rate?
questions.solution:
The net acid excretion rate can be calculated using the following formula:

Net acid excretion rate = Urinary acid excretion rate - Bicarbonate reabsorption rate

Urinary acid excretion rate = Hydrogen ion secretion rate

Bicarbonate reabsorption rate = Filtered bicarbonate - Excreted bicarbonate

Filtered bicarbonate = Plasma bicarbonate concentration × glomerular filtration rate

Excreted bicarbonate = Bicarbonate concentration in urine × urine flow rate

Substituting the given values in the formula:

Net acid excretion rate = 200 mmol/day - [20 mmol/L × (125 mL/min × 1440 min/day) / 1000] = 60 mmol/day

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, page 319

questions.text: Which of the following intermuscular septa is not present in the thigh?
questions.solution:
Intermuscular septa of the thigh:

Three intermuscular septa divide the thigh into three compartments.

  • The lateralintermuscular septum is the thickest of these septa. It extends from the iliotibial tract to the lateral lip of the linea aspera. It separates the anterior compartment of the thigh from the posterior compartment.
  • The medialintermuscular septum is attached to the medial lip of the linea aspera. It separates the anterior compartment of the thigh from the medial compartment.
  • The posteriorintermuscular septum is poorly defined. It separates the medial compartment of the thigh from the posterior compartment.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page No - 50

questions.text:
Out of the statements given below about Wallerian degeneration, which are true and which are false?
1. It was discovered by Augustus Waller.
2. Seen after 3 degrees of injury to the entire nerve trunk.
3. Changes are seen distal to the injured stump.
4. First change after injury is chromatolysis.
5. Chromatolysis occurs in the axon's membrane.
6. Nucleus is pushed towards the periphery after the cell imbibes water and swells.
questions.solution:
• Orthograde degeneration (Wallerian degeneration) occurs from the point of injury to the nerve terminal, interrupting neural transmission. Distal to the injury, the membrane breaks down and the myelin sheath degenerates. The proximal axon also is affected and may undergo retrograde degeneration and die. The cell body of the injured neuron swells, the nucleus moves to an eccentric position, and the rough endoplasmic reticulum gets fragmented (chromatolytic reaction).
  • Seen after 5 degrees of injury.
  • Chromatolysis occurs in the cell body.
  • First change in Wallerian Degeneration is axonal degeneration.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition. Pg. 85-97

questions.text: Where is the foramen of Weitbrecht present?
questions.solution:
The capsular ligament of shoulder joint:

  • It is very loose and permits free movements.
  • It is least supported inferiorly where dislocations are common. Such a dislocation may damage the closely related axillary nerve.
  • Medially, the capsule is attached to the scapula beyond the supraglenoid tubercle and the margins of the labrum.
  • Laterally, it is attached to the anatomical neck of the humerus with the following exceptions.
  • Inferiorly, the attachment extends down to the surgical neck.
  • Superiorly, it is deficient for passage of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii.
  • Anteriorly, the capsule is reinforced by supplemental bands called the superior, middle and inferior glenohumeral ligaments. The area between the superior and middle glenohumeral ligament is a point of weakness in the capsule (foramen of Weitbrecht) which is a common site of anterior dislocation of the humeral head.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page No - 158

questions.text:
A patient presented with symptoms of muscle weakness and his age was around 10 to 15 years old. He was on a wheelchair and chief complaints were respiratory problems which were progressing with time. A diagnosis of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy was made.
Which of the following statements are true regarding his condition?
1. It only affects males
2. It is a disorder of the titin gene
3. It is not an inherited disorder
4. Common symptoms of this disease are failing and wasting in the distal muscles of the lower limbs that can later be identified in other body areas
5. It does not have any specific treatment. Only symptomatic management via steroids can be given, although gene therapy is a potential future treatment.
questions.solution:
Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy -

  • Disease affects only males because it is transmitted as an X-linked recessive trait and is caused by mutation of the gene that encodes for a protein called dystrophin, which links actin to the proteins in the muscle cell membrane.
  • Dystrophin and associated proteins form an interface between the intracellular contractile apparatus and extracellular connective matrix.
  • Lack of dystrophin or mutated forms of the protein cause muscle cell membrane destabilization and activation of multiple pathophysiological processes, including altered intracellular calcium handling and impaired membrane repair after injury.
  • One important effect of abnormal dystrophin is an increase in membrane permeability to calcium, thus allowing extracellular calcium ions to enter the muscle fiber and initiate changes in intracellular enzymes that ultimately lead to proteolysis and muscle fiber breakdown.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Edition Pg91

questions.text: Sustentacular cells in paraganglioma stain positive for which of the following?
questions.solution:
The chief cells, which are neuroectodermal in origin, stain strongly for neuroendocrine markers including chromogranin, synaptophysin, neuron-specific enolase, CD56, and CD57.

The supporting network of spindle-shaped stromal cells, collectively called sustentacular cells, are positive for S-100 protein.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease 10th ed. Pg 746

questions.solution: Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th ed. Pg 1045

questions.text: Which of the following information can be omitted as it is not necessary to be mentioned in the drug promotional literature (DPL) for the purpose of promotion of the drug?
questions.solution:
According to the WHO criteria and OPPI (Organization of Pharmaceutical Producers of India) code of Pharmaceutical practices 2012, the printed drug promotional literature(DPL) must contain -

  • Name of the drug: Brand name should be available with the active ingredient (generic name). The ratio of size of brand name to generic name should not be more than 3:1
  • Indications: Approved therapeutic indications must be present on the DPL.
  • Dosage: Content of active ingredient(s) per dosage form and whole regiment should be written on the DPL
  • Precautions and warnings
  • Contraindications
  • Adverse effects: All serious adverse effects and common non serious adverse effects should be mentioned on the DPL
  • Major interactions
  • Price: Price of the drug as well as the whole regimen should be present on DPL.
  • Information of manufacturer: The name and address of the pharmaceutical company or its agent responsible for marketing the product must be present on DPL
  • Reference to scientific literature: Appropriate references should be available regarding the claims made by the DPL.

Reference: WHO criteria for drug advertisement, Practical Manual of Pharmacology by Dinesh Badyal 1st /e p211-212

questions.text: Match the following images of various polyps with their correct labels.
questions.solution:
Hyperplastic polyp

  • Histologically, hyperplastic polyps are composed of mature goblet and absorptive cells with a serrated surface architecture that is the morphologic hallmark of these lesions. Serration is typically restricted to the upper third of the crypt.

Juvenile polyp

  • Microscopic examination shows dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. The remainder of the polyp is composed of lamina propria expanded by mixed inflammatory infiltrates. The muscularis mucosae may be normal or attenuated.

Peutz-Jeghers Polyp

  • Histologic examination demonstrates a characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th ed. Pg 807- 810

questions.text: Which of the following is not an immune checkpoint inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Immune checkpoint inhibitors:

Normally, there are certain checkpoints, so that immune cells (like T-cells) do not attack self antigens. Certain receptors like PD-1(programmed death receptors) or CTLA-4(cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein) are present on T-cells. When ligands on other cells (PDL-1 or CD-80/86 respectively) bind to these receptors, T-cells are inhibited. Same method is utilized by some cancer cells to evade destruction from T-cells. These tumor cells overexpress the ligands like PDL-1 and inhibit T-cells. Monoclonal antibodies targeting these interactions result in disinhibition of these brakes and thus, T-cells can destroy cancer cells.

  • PD-1 and PDL-1 inhibitors
    • Nivolumab, Pembrolizumaband Cemiplimab are monoclonal antibodies against PD-1 receptors on T-cells.
    • Atezolizumab, Avelumaband Durvalumab are monoclonal antibodies against PDL-1 present on cancer cells.
  • CTLA-4 Inhibitor:
    • Normally CD-80 or CD-86 present on antigen presenting cells bind to CD- 28 present on T-cells. Cytotoxic T-lymphocyte Antigen-4 (CTLA-4) is a CD-28 homologue expressed on T-cells. Binding of this with CD-80/86 molecules inhibit the T-cells. Ipilimumabacts as CTLA-4 inhibitor resulting in T-cell activation and destruction of cancer cells. It is approved for treatment of malignant melanoma.

Reference: Goodman &Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th/e p629

questions.text: A 40-yr old man with a chronic history of alcohol abuse develops severe hematemesis and succumbs. At autopsy, collapsed esophageal varices are observed. Which of the following is the next most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
This is a case of rupture of esophageal varices. Varices are common in patients with cirrhosis, most frequently due to alcoholic liver disease. Worldwide, hepatic schistosomiasis is the second most common cause of varices.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th ed. Pg 760

questions.text: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is an adverse effect observed with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Adverse Effects of Gemcitabine -

  • The principal toxicity is myelosuppression. Longer duration infusions lead to greater myelosuppression and hepatic toxicity.
  • Non hematological toxicities include a flu-likesyndrome, asthenia, and rarely a posterior leukoencephalopathy Mild, reversible elevation in liver transaminases may occur in 40% or more of patients. Interstitial pneumonitis, at times progressing to ARDS, may occur within the first two cycles of treatment and usually responds to corticosteroids.
  • Rarely, patients treated for many months may develop a slowly progressive hemolytic uremic syndrome, necessitating drug discontinuation. Gemcitabine is a very potent radiosensitizer and should not be used with radiotherapy.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th/e p1184

questions.text: The current WHO classification proposes positive staining for which of the following markers as a criterion for classifying otherwise poorly-differentiated non-small cell carcinomas as adenocarcinomas?
questions.solution:
Thyroid transcription factor 1, which is consistently expressed in normal type 2 pneumocytes and Clara cells, has emerged as one of the most useful markers of epithelial lung tumors.

Given relatively high sensitivity and specificity, the current WHO classification scheme proposes positive staining for TTF-1 (or napsin A) as a criterion for classifying otherwise poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinomas as adenocarcinomas.

The current WHO classification of lung tumors suggests that diffuse staining for p63 or p40 should be used as a criterion for classifying TTF-1 negative poorly differentiated non-small cell lung carcinomas as squamous cell carcinomas.

Reference: Rosai and Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th ed. Pg 401

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Daclizumab is-
questions.solution:
IL-2 receptor antagonists

  • The CD-25 molecule is expressed on the surface of immunologically activated, but not resting T-cells. The CD-25 acts as a high affinity receptor for IL-2 through which cell proliferation and differentiation are promoted.
  • Some anti CD-25 antibodies have been developed as IL-2 receptor antagonists to specifically arrest the activated T-cells.
  • Daclizumabis a highly humanized chimeric monoclonal anti CD-25 antibody which binds to and acts as IL-2 receptor antagonist.
  • Combined with glucocorticoids, calcineurin antagonists and/or azathioprine/MMF, it is used to prevent renal and other transplant rejection reactions.
  • Basiliximabis another anti CD-25 antibody with higher affinity for the IL-2 receptor, but shorter plasma t½ (1 week). Clinical use of basiliximab is similar to that of daclizumab.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p943

choices.text: Positive test for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase
Antibodies directed against the A blood group antigen

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency room with complaints of dyspnea and a productive cough. His vital signs are a temperature of 101°F, pulse of 106 bpm, and blood pressure of 137/87 mm Hg. Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin of 11.1 mg/dL, a white blood cell count of 900 cells/µL, and platelet count of 87,000 cells/µL. A physical examination reveals a palpable spleen, and rales on the right side. Of the following, what would further laboratory testing most likely identify?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario (an older male with pancytopenia and splenomegaly) is consistent with hairy cellleukemia, and the cell illustrated in the blood smear in the image is hairy cell leukemia.
  • The characteristic laboratory abnormality in hairy cell leukemia is a positive test for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase.
  • A t(9;22) translocation is found in CML and some forms of ALL.
  • A t(11;14) is found in mantle cell lymphoma.
  • A positive mono spot test would indicate an EBV infection, which can result in atypical lymphocytes, but these have a more abundant cytoplasm and abut adjacent red blood cells.
  • Antibodies directed against the A blood group antigen are not characteristic of hairy cell leukemia.

Reference: Robbins, 10th ed, Pg- 477

questions.text: A 32-year-old female has acute bacterial rhino-sinusitis and is to receive an oral antibiotic. She complains of a headache and fever. Blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, heart rate 100/min, temperature 37.8°C (100.1°F). Amoxicillin is a weak organic acid with a pKa of 2. What percentage of a given dose will be in the water-soluble form in the duodenum at a pH of 4?
questions.solution:
Many drugs are weak bases or weak acids. For such molecules, the pH of the medium determines the fraction of molecules charged (ionized) versus uncharged (nonionized). If the pKa of the drug and the pH of the medium are known, the fraction of molecules in the ionized state can be predicted by means of the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation

Amoxicillin is an acid, so it is more ionized at alkaline pH and less ionized at acidic pH. The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation predicts that the ratio changes from 50/50 at the pH equal to the pKa to 1/10 (protonated/unprotonated) at 1 pH unit more alkaline than the pKa and 1/100 at 2 pH units more alkaline. For acids, unprotonated form is ionized, So about 99% part is water-soluble form.

Reference: Goodman &Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics

choices.text: Only i, ii, and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following/s criteria/s is/are required for the diagnosis of Essential thrombocytosis?
i Megakaryocytosis
ii Eosinophilia
iii Presence of JAK 2 mutation
iv Thrombocytopenia.
questions.solution:
• Essential thrombocytosisis a clonal disorder in which there is rise in platelet counts in the absence of any recognisable stimuli. The overproduction of platelets are from megakaryocytic colonies. The underlying mechanism is the absence of control of thrombopoietin that regulates the endomitosis in the megakaryocyte to produce platelets.
  • The condition is more common in older patients. Hemorrhagic and thrombotic events are common.
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Elevated platelets
    • Blood film shows large platelets, megakaryocytes and hypogranular forms.
    • Abnormal platelet function i.e. platelet aggregation.
    • Bone marrow reveals a large number of hyperdiploid megakaryocytes and variable amounts of increased fibrosis.

Reference: Harsh Mohan, 6th ed, Pg- 360

choices.text: A 57-year-old man with cirrhosis: reduced dose of sotalol
A 35-year-old man with renal disease: reduced dose of meperidine
A 97-year-old man with normal creatinine and bilirubin: reduced dose of diazepam
A 42-year-old man with cirrhosis: reduced dose of meperidine

questions.text: All of the following patients are correctly matched to the drug and dose adjustment that should be considered given their concomitant listed comorbidity except-
questions.solution:
Sotalol is almost exclusively renally cleared, and dose reduction should be considered in patients with renal disease.

Meperidine undergoes extensive hepatic metabolism, so that renal failure has little effect on its plasma concentration. However, its metabolite, normeperidine, does undergo renal excretion, accumulates in renal failure, and probably accounts for the signs of central nervous system (CNS) excitation, such as irritability, twitching, and seizures, that appear when multiple doses of meperidine are administered to patients with renal disease (options B and D).

Adverse drug reactions are especially common in the elderly because of altered pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics, the frequent use of multidrug regimens, and concomitant disease. For example, use of long half-life benzodiazepines is linked to the occurrence of hip fractures in elderly patients (option C).

Reference: Basic and Clinical Pharmacology by Bertram Katzung, 14th ed, pg 48

questions.text: Splenic infarction is associated with -
questions.solution:
Causes of splenic infarcts:

  • Hematological disorders: sickle cell anemia, Polycythemia vera, Hypercoagulable state, CML, Leukemia, Lymphoma, Myelofibrosis, Erythropoietin therapy
  • Embolic disorders: Arterial fibrillation, Endocarditis, HIV associated mycobacterial infections
  • Collagen vascular disorders: SLE, Kawasaki disease, Wegner’s granulomatosis, PAN
  • Infections: Infectious mononucleosis, Kala-azar, Meningococemia, Clostridium perfringens, Salmonellosis, P.Vivax, Falciparum, Leptospirosis
  • Trauma
  • Miscellaneous: Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, ARDS, Splenic vein thrombosis, Liver transplant

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-634

choices.text: Ibuprofen and warfarin: increased risk of GI bleeding; ibuprofen inhibition of CYP2C9
Sotalol and furosemide: increased risk of QT prolongation and torsades de pointes; furosemide induced inhibition of CYP3A4
Sildenafil and sublingual nitroglycerin: increased risk of hypotension; sildenafil inhibition of the PDE - 5 that inactivates cyclic guanosine monophosphate
Ritonavir and lovastatin: increased risk of myotoxicity; ritonavir inhibition of CYP2C19

questions.text: Which of the following sets of drug-drug interactions and their mechanism is accurately described?
questions.solution:
Sildenafil and nitroglycerin should not be co-prescribed. The pharmacologic effects of sildenafil result from inhibition of the PDE-5 that inactivates GMP in the vasculature. Nitroglycerin and related nitrates used to treat angina produce vasodilation by elevating cyclic GMP. Thus, co-administration of these nitrates with sildenafil can cause profound hypotension, which can be catastrophic in patients with coronary disease.

NSAIDs cause gastric ulcers and in patients treated with warfarin, the risk of upper gastrointestinal bleeding is increased almost threefold by concomitant use of an NSAID such as ibuprofen. This is not mediated by inhibition of a cytochrome P450 enzyme(option A).

Torsades de pointes ventricular tachycardia during administration of QT-prolonging antiarrhythmics(quinidine, sotalol, dofetilide) occurs much more frequently in patients receiving diuretics, probably reflecting hypokalemia instead of inhibition of any cytochrome P450 enzyme(option B).

Ritonavir is a powerful inhibitor of CYP3A4(not 2C19)(option D) and should not be co-prescribed with lovastatin.

Reference: Basic and Clinical Pharmacology by Bertram Katzung, 14th ed, pg 62

questions.text: A 65-yr old female presents to OPD with painful joints, fatigue and anorexia, with significant weight loss. On examination, splenomegaly with generalized lymphadenopathy is noted. Her CBC shows Hb 8.3 gm/dL, WBC count of 96x109/L and platelet count of 201x109/L. Her differential counts show - Neutrophils - 10% and Lymphocytes - 90%. Her peripheral smear is shown in the image. Her Coomb's test is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of chronic lymphocytic leukemia(CLL). The peripheral blood smear shown in the image is flooded with small lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm. A characteristic finding is the presence of disrupted tumor cells(smudge cells), two of which are present in this smear.

Patients are often asymptomatic at diagnosis. When symptoms appear, they are nonspecific and include easy fatigability, weight loss and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are present in 50% to 60% of symptomatic patients. The leukocyte count is highly variable.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th ed, Pg 598

questions.text:
A 38-year-old farmer has been accidentally exposed to a high concentration of a highly toxic agricultural organophosphate insecticide. What would be the sign/symptom of the condition?
1. Sweating
2. Urination
3. Vomiting
4. Bradycardia
5. Mydriasis
6. Bronchorrhea
7. Hyperventilation
questions.solution:
OP poison causes irreversible acetylcholinesterase inhibition and produces following effects.

  • Muscarinic effects
    • Excess of secretions, including salivation, sweating, lacrimation, urination, defecation and emesis
    • Miosis and blurred vision
    • Bradycardia
    • Bronchospasm
    • Bronchorrhea
  • Nicotinic effects: blockage at the neuromuscular junction(similar mechanism observed in succinylcholine)
    • Systemic effects
    • Hypoventilation
    • Lethargy
    • Seizures, coma

Reference: Basic and Clinical Pharmacology by Bertram Katzung, 14th ed

questions.text: Hemoglobin M is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Methemoglobinemia can occur because of either acquired or inherited defects in the methemoglobin reductase system or because of the presence of a structurally abnormal globin chain. In the latter case, the defect results in increased formation of methemoglobin by rendering the molecule relatively resistant to reduction by methemoglobin reductase. This structural variant of hemoglobin is called hemoglobin M(HbM).

Reference: Clinical laboratory hematology 4th ed, Shirlyn McKenzie, Pg 284

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with end-stage multiple sclerosis who is on prednisone and neostigmine. After examination, the patient has begun on dalfampridine. What is the most likely mechanism of action for this medication?
questions.solution:
Dalfampridine, a potassium channel blocker administered orally, improves walking speeds versus placebo. It is the first drug approved for this use. Currently approved MS drugs are indicated to decrease relapse rates or in some cases, to prevent accumulation of disability.

  • Nifedipine is an example of a calcium channel blocker.
  • Pyridostigmine is an example of a cholinesterase inhibitor.
  • Anticholinergic agents do not work through blockade of sodium channels.

Reference: Basic and Clinical Pharmacology by Bertram Katzung, 14th ed, pg 112

Due to similar history in the elder sibling, genetic work-up was done and mutation in RPS 19 gene was noted, diagnosing the boy as a case of Diamond Blackman Anemia. questions.text:
A 3-year-old child has been presented to the ED having swallowed 10 tablets as shown below. Which of the following are signs of the toxicity that may occur in this child?
1. Bronchoconstriction
2. Tachycardia
3. Mydriasis
4. Renin release from the kidneys
5. Vasoconstriction of blood vessels
6. Urinary retention
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario suggests toxicity of phenylephrine, a potent, selective α-adrenoceptor agonist drug, which is used as a nasal decongestant as an over the counter drug.

Phenylephrine acts as a nasal decongestant by reducing hyperemia and mucosal edema. It can also be used in

  • Hypotension
  • Rhinitis, obstructed Eustachian tubes
  • Nasal decongestant
  • Allergic conjunctivitis
  • Open-angle glaucoma
  • Ischemic priapism(high-dose intracavernosal phenylephrine injection)

How to approach individual actions in the ANS -

  • Bronchoconstriction = by parasympathetic on M3 receptor(bronchial smooth muscle), not α-adrenoceptor
  • Tachycardia = by sympathetic on β1 receptor(SA node), not α-adrenoceptor
  • Mydriasis = by α1-adrenoceptor on radial muscle on iris
  • Renin release from the kidneys = by sympathetic on β1 receptor(JG cells), not α-adrenoceptor
  • Vasoconstriction of blood vessels = by α1-adrenoceptor on vascular smooth muscle
  • Urinary retention = by α1-adrenoceptor on urinary sphincter

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition By Bertram G. Katzung, Pg no. 145

questions.text: Abnormality of the ferrochelatase enzyme causes -
questions.solution:
Erythropoietic protoporphyria is characterized by an accumulation of protoporphyrin due to an abnormality of the ferrochelatase enzyme.

Reference: Clinical laboratory hematology, 4th ed, Shirlyn McKenzie, Pg 257

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for intermittent episodes of sharp chest pain and palpitations. She appears nervous. Her pulse is 115/min and irregularly irregular and blood pressure is 139/86 mmHg. Examination shows a fine tremor on both hands and digital swelling; the extremities are warm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The condition underlying this patient's arrhythmia causes a state of adrenergic hyperactivity due to hyperthyroidism.
  • Propranolol is indicated for the immediate control of symptoms in patients with hyperthyroidism. Thyroid hormones affect cardiac myocytes directly and also stimulate proliferation of beta-adrenergic receptors, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias as seen in this patient. Beta blockers decrease the adrenergic tone and therefore improve tachycardia, hypertension, muscle weakness, tremor and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Propranolol, in high doses, also decreases the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting the 5', monodeiodinase enzyme.

Option A: Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant. Patients with atrial fibrillation(AF) are at increased risk of developing thromboembolic complications, which is why long-term anticoagulation is indicated when the CHA2DS2-VASc score is ≥ 2 or when AF is caused by valvular disease. Although this patient has features of AF(irregularly irregular pulse), her CHA2DS2-VASc score is 1 and she has no history of valvular disease.

Option C: Propylthiouracil(PTU) is an antithyroid drug that is used in the medical treatment for hyperthyroidism, of which this patient shows sign and symptoms. However, symptomatic treatment should be started for immediate control of symptoms.

Option D: Amiodarone is used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia and persisting ventricular fibrillation(VF) after unsuccessful defibrillation, as well as the long-term treatment of refractory supraventricular arrhythmia(atrial fibrillation). Because of the high levels of iodine in amiodarone, it may aggravate pre-existing thyroid conditions.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition By Bertram G. Katzung, Pg. 168

questions.text: A young man aged 30 years, presents with difficulty in vision in the left eye for the last 10 days. He is immunocompetent, a farmer by occupation, comes from a rural community and gives history of trauma to his left eye with vegetative matter 10-15 days back. On examinations, there is an ulcerative lesion in the cornea, whose base has raised soft creamy infiltrate. Ulcer margin is feathery and hyphae. Branching, aseptate hyphae were noted. There are a few satellite lesions also. Corneal scraping shows sickle shaped macro conidia. What should be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fusarium is a hyaline filamentous fungi, which may cause a range of opportunistic infections in humans.

In humans with normal immune systems, fusarium infections may occur in the nails(onychomycosis) and in the cornea (keratomycosis or mycotic keratitis).

It is diagnosed by the presence of sickle shaped macroconidia.

Reference: Sastry, 3rd ed, pg 789

questions.text: What proportion of individuals between 65 and 80 years of age have marked loss of olfactory function?
questions.solution:
According to a study in which the University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test was administered to 1,955 persons spanning the entire age range, more than 75% of individuals over the age of 80 years evidenced major olfactory impairment, with nearly 50% being anosmic. More than half of persons between 65 and 80 years of age evidenced major olfactory impairment, with nearly a quarter being anosmic. Such losses are significant and place many older persons at risk from fire, leaking natural gas and spoiled food, as well as from malnutrition from a lack of interest in food secondary to lack of flavor.

Reference: Ballenger’s otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, chapter no 27, Olfaction and Gustation, page no 573

questions.text: Identify the image.
questions.solution: Reference: Sastry, 3rd ed, pg 682, 683

choices.text: Local airway release of inflammatory mediators

questions.text: Which of the following is not a proposed mechanism for the negative effect of allergic rhinitis on asthma?
questions.solution:
Allergic rhinitis has a close relationship with asthma. Numerous studies have shown a high incidence of allergic rhinitis in asthmatics and control of nasal allergies is thought to reduce asthma severity. There is growing evidence to support the systemic response to a local allergic reaction; hence, through this mechanism, nasal allergies could cause disease distally in the airway. Inflammatory mediators could also be released into the airway, travel to the lower respiratory tract and induce inflammatory disease in that location. Challenge of the lower airway with antigen has been shown to cause allergic inflammation in the nose, suggesting the possibility of nasopulmonary neurogenic reflexes. Asthmatics have been shown to have a decreased ability to condition cold, dry air. Additionally, patients with seasonal allergic rhinitis out of season have a reduced ability to warm and humidify air. These studies raise the possibility that nasal conditioning capacity may affect lower airways disease. Although allergic rhinitis frequently causes nasal obstruction and may affect nasal breathing during sleep, this is not a proposed mechanism to explain the relationship between asthma and allergic rhinitis.

Reference: Ballenger’s otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, chapter no 32, Allergic Rhinitis, page no 709

questions.text: A 45-year man complains of high grade fever, malaise and body ache for 4 days. He has recently returned from a vacation in Brazil. Laboratory investigation reveals pancytopenia and decreased hemoglobin. A blood smear shows ring shaped trophozoites inside RBCs. Many RBCs have >1 ring. Rapid Antigen Test(RAT) for HRP-II antigen was negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Babesia are intraerythrocytic coccidian parasites that morphologically resemble plasmodia. They are causing malaria-like illness and can lead to severe anemia with hemoglobinuria. They occur as trophozoite form inside RBC. As more than one ring per RBC is present, they morphologically confuse with Plasmodium falciparum. The distinguished features include absence of schizonts & gametocytes and presence of tetrads(four ring) that is maltese cross appearance are pathognomonic of babesia.

Reference: Paniker’s textbook of Parasitology, 8th Edition, Pg No. 87

questions.text: A 20-year-old man complains of left-sided nasal obstruction that began spontaneously 2 years ago. There have been no other nasal symptoms and otolaryngologic examination, including rigid endoscopy, is entirely normal, as was a computed tomography(CT) scan of the sinuses. Medical therapy in the form of intranasal corticosteroids has proved ineffective and the patient insists that nasal surgery be performed. Which investigation would best clarify the situation?
questions.solution:
Active anterior rhinomanometry will provide information about the airway and will assist in counseling the patient, particularly when surgical intervention is inappropriate. Nasal inspiratory peak flow measures both sides of the nose together and has a broad range of normality. Magnetic resonance imaging is unlikely to be helpful if the CT scan and endoscopy are normal. The nasal and sinus mucosa has a good blood supply and generally gives a high signal; mild inflammatory changes may persist for weeks and months after an upper respiratory tract infection and this may lead to a confusing overdiagnosis of disease. Tests of mucociliary function will not clarify the cause of the obstruction and are unlikely to be abnormal in the absence of other symptoms.

Reference: Ballenger’s otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, chapter no 33, Acute and Chronic Nasal Disorders, page no 743

questions.text:
Match following parasites with their mode of infection.
A. Naegleria fowleri
B. Entamoeba histolytica
C. Ancylostoma duodenale
D. Wuchereria bancrofti
1. Bite of vector
2. Skin penetration
3. Mucosal penetration
4. Ingestion
questions.solution:
Naegleria fowleri is a free-living amoeba which is present in freshwater lakes and reservoirs. Infection is acquired when a patient is taking a bath in infected water. Parasite enters through penetrating nasal mucosa.

Entamoeba histolytica is an amoeba in which infection is acquired through ingestion of contaminated food or water.

Ancylostoma duodenale is a nematode in which infective filariform larvae are present in soil. Person when walk barefoot on faecally contaminated soil, larvae enter the body through skin penetration.

Wuchereria bancrofti is nematode in which infection acquired through bite of infected mosquito-species of Culex like C.fatigans or C.quinquefasciatus.

Reference: Paniker’s textbook of Parasitology, 8th Edition, Pg. No. 4

questions.text: Poor prognostic factors among nasal and paranasal sinus malignancies include all of the following except
questions.solution:
The role of histologic subtype has not been clearly defined. It has not been associated with prognosis in many reports and other authors have suggested improved survival among adenoid cystic carcinoma and lymphoma and poorer survival rates in undifferentiated carcinoma as well as melanoma. These data are of limited value because of the different treatment regimens employed and the small number of patients studied.

Reference: Ballenger’s otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, chapter no 36, Neoplasms of the Nose and Paranasal Sinuses, page no 814

questions.text: All except one of the following signs are oral manifestations of leukemia -
questions.solution:
In addition to being anemic and thrombocytopenic, patients with leukemia are often neutropenic and secondary infections of the oral cavity and oropharynx commonly occur, resulting in necrosis and ulceration of the mucous membranes. Leukemic infiltration of the gums is common, causing gingival hypertrophy, edema, inflammation and bleeding.

Reference: Ballenger’s otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, chapter no 44, Diseases of the Oral Cavity, Oropharynx and Nasopharynx, page no 1023

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of viral replication?
questions.solution:
Viral Replication passes through six steps.

  1. Attachment: occurs via specific receptors (Eg. HIV attaches via gp120 to CD4 receptor)
  2. Penetration: via fusion, nucleocapsid enters while envelope stays outside
  3. Uncoating: by action of lysosomal enzymes, nucleic acid is released in cytoplasm
  4. Multiplication: synthesis of nucleic acid, capsid protein, enzymes, regulatory proteins
  5. Release: via BUDDING in enveloped viruses and LYSIS in non-enveloped virus

Site of replication:

  • DNA viruses- in nucleus ( except Poxvirus, occurs in cytoplasm)
  • RNA viruses- in cytoplasm (except Orthomyxovirus, occurs in nucleus)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, pg 80

choices.text: Eardrum intubation, if necessary, will likely require a trip to the operating room
A second-look surgery may be required in cases of cholesteatoma removal

questions.text: Which of the following statements apply to the postoperative period following cartilage tympanoplasty?
questions.solution:
While the tympanic membrane remains relatively insensate after cartilage reconstruction, it is often necessary to take the patient to the operating room for eardrum intubation as tube placement can be difficult. Impedance tympanometry is unreliable after cartilage tympanoplasty and will generally yield a low-volume, type B tympanogram, despite normal hearing, due to the noncompliant nature of the cartilage. One serious disadvantage of using cartilage for reconstruction in cholesteatoma surgery is that it creates an opaque tympanic membrane posteriorly, which could potentially hide residual disease. If disruption of the cholesteatoma sac occurs, consider the advisability of performing a second-look surgery. The most significant pitfall seen in the postoperative period is persistent effusion with conductive hearing loss, requiring intubation of the reconstructed eardrum. This is seen in about 7% to 10% of cases and can be problematic in cases in which the entire tympanic membrane is reconstructed with the cartilage/perichondrium island flap.

Reference: Otologic surgery by breakmann 4th edition chapter 9 Cartilage Tympanoplasty page 112

choices.text: Each relapse is associated with an antigenically distinct variant.
Blood smears should be made when the patient is afebrile

questions.text: A 26 year old patient comes to your hospital with a history of 4 episodes of fever for 4 to 5 days followed by afebrile period of 6-7 days. On performing a peripheral blood smear by giemsa stain the following picture was seen. All the following statements regarding the disease in this patient is true except:
questions.solution:
The above case is of relapsing fever. The point towards the disease are: relapse of fever and the peripheral smear shows Borrelia species in giemsa stain.

Relapsing fever (RF) is characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and nonspecific symptoms following exposure to insect vector carrying Borrelia species.

Relapsing fever is of two types:

  • Epidemic RF: It is caused by B. recurrentis and transmitted by louse.
  • Endemic RF is caused by Borrelia species other than B. recurrentis such as B. duttonii, B. hermsii and turicatae. It is transmitted by tick.

The borrelial surface antigens frequently undergo antigenic variation. Each time, new antigens are produced which can evade the host's immune system leading to repeated bacteremia and recurrent febrile episodes.

Clinical Manifestations.

  • Both epidemic and endemic RF have similar manifestations although not identical.
  • Incubation period is about 7-8 days.
  • Recurrent febrile episodes lasting for 3-5 days occur intervening with afebrile periods of 4-14 days. Relapses can occur up to 10 times; subsequent episodes are shorter.
  • Hemorrhages: Petechiae, epistaxis and blood-tinged sputum are more likely in epidemic RF.
  • Neurologic features such as meningitis, seizure, focal deficits, paraplegia and psychosis may occur in 10-30% of cases and are more common in epidemic RF.

Treatment: doxycycline or erythromycin are the drug of choice for relapsing fever.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 323

choices.text: Coiling properties of the cartilaginous skeleton
Active contraction of the associated muscles
Pressure of tissues neighboring the lumen

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to the closing of the lumen of the Eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
Closure of the ET is thought to be the result of the following factors: the recoiling memory properties of the cartilaginous ET, the relaxing bulk of the TVP muscle, and pressure of neighboring paraluminal tissue. The closed lumen is likely maintained by all of the above and aided by the surface tension of the apposed wet mucosal surfaces.

Reference: Otologic surgery by breakmann 4th edition chapter 6 Diagnosis and Management of the Patulous Eustachian Tube page 77

choices.text: Increased expression of MHC class I molecules
Decreased expression of MHC class I molecules
Increased expression of MHC class II molecules
Decreased expression of MHC class II molecules

questions.text: NK cells kill the viral infected cells due to-
questions.solution:
While on patrol NK cells constantly contact other cells. Whether or not the NK cell kills these cells depends on a balance of signals from activating receptors and inhibitory receptors on the NK cell surface.

Activating receptors recognise molecules that are expressed on the surface of cancer cells and infected cells, and 'switch on' the NK cell. Inhibitory receptors act as a check on NK cell killing.

Most normal healthy cells express MHC I receptors which mark these cells as 'self'. Inhibitory receptors on the surface of the NK cell recognise cognate MHC I, and this 'switches off' the NK cell, preventing it from killing. Cancer cells and infected cells often lose their MHC I, leaving them vulnerable to NK cell killing. Once the decision is made to kill, the NK cell releases cytotoxic granules containing perforin and granzymes, which leads to lysis of the target cell.

Reference: https://www.immunology.org/public-information/bitesized-immunology/cells/natural-killer-cells

questions.text: Placental crossing of immunoglobulin is mediated by expression of which of the following on syncytiotrophoblast cells?
questions.solution:
• IgG is the only antibody class that significantly crosses the human placenta.
  • This crossing is mediated by FcRn expressed on syncytiotrophoblast cells.
  • This confers natural short term (6 months) passive immunity to newborn.
  • The transport of IgG antibodies across the placenta is known to occur especially in the third trimester of pregnancy, and as more time passes, more antibodies cross.
  • IgG1 is the most efficiently transported subclass and IgG2 the least.
  • IgM antibodies are restricted from crossing the placenta due to their size.
  • IgA and IgD also cannot cross the placenta.

The neonatal Fc receptor of IgG [FcRn] is well characterized for the passive placental transfer of humoral immunity from mother to fetus. FcRn binds to the Fc portion of IgG.

Reference: Damas, Oriana & Deshpande, Amar & Avalos, Danny & Abreu, Maria. (2015). Treating Inflammatory Bowel Disease in Pregnancy: The Issues We Face Today. Journal of Crohn's & colitis. 9. 10.1093/ecco-jcc/jjv118

questions.text: Albendazole is the drug of choice for -
questions.solution:
Albendazole, a broad-spectrum oral anthelmintic, is the drug of choice and is approved in the USA for treatment of hydatid disease and cysticercosis. It is also used in the treatment of pinworm and hookworm infections, ascariasis, trichuriasis, and strongyloidiasis.

Reference: Basic & clinical pharmacology by Bertram G. Katzung, 12th edition, page no. 937

questions.text: Post disaster, which of the following does not spread as an epidemic?
questions.solution:
Diseases associated with natural disasters

  • Waterborne diseases - E coli, V cholerae, hepatitis A & E, leptospirosis
  • Overcrowding- Measles, meningitis, acute respiratory illness
  • Vector borne diseases - Malaria, dengue
  • Zoonoses- Rickettsiosis, equine encephalitis and rabies
  • Other associated diseases- tetanus, coccidiomycosis

Reference: WHO website Communicable disease following natural disaster

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of cystic fibrosis is brought to the hospital for a lung transplant. Immunosuppressive therapy is begun with mycophenolate mofetil to prevent tissue rejection. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
• Mycophenolate mofetil is converted to the active metabolite mycophenolic acid, which is potent, selective, uncompetitive, and reversible inhibitor of inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH) and thus inhibits de-novo synthesis of the guanine nucleotide. Subsequent lymphocyte proliferation depends on this purine synthesis. This agent is indicated for the prophylaxis of organ rejection in patients receiving allogeneic renal, cardiac or hepatic transplants.
  • Mycophenolate should be used concomitantly with cyclosporine and a corticosteroid, such as prednisone.
  • Common adverse effects seen with this medication include hypertension, infection, peripheral edema, and hypercholesterolemia. Serious reactions include thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, neutropenia, immunosuppression, and opportunistic infections.
  • Tacrolimus is a macrolide immunosuppressant produced by Streptomyces tsukubaensis, which is a species of Actinobacteria. This agent inhibits calcineurin-mediated transcription of IL-2.. Tacrolimus specifically binds the immunophilin FK506-binding protein. This agent is indicated for kidney, heart, and liver transplant rejection prophylaxis.
  • Cyclosporine has a very similar mechanism of action. It binds cyclophilin and inhibits calcineurin-mediated transcription of interleukin-2 production, which reduces subsequent T-cell activation. Cyclosporine is indicated for kidney, heart, and liver transplant rejection prophylaxis. Common adverse effects seen with this medication include tremor, hypertension, infection, and renal impairment. Serious reactions include thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, neutropenia, immunosuppression, nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, seizures, and opportunistic infections.
  • Daclizumab and basiliximab are antibodies with high-affinity for the IL-2 receptor on activated T cells. These immunosuppressant agents act by binding to activated lymphocyte IL-2 receptor alpha chains, antagonizing IL-2. Daclizumab is indicated for kidney transplant rejection prophylaxis when used as part of an immunosuppressive regimen including cyclosporine and corticosteroids.
  • Basiliximab is a similar immunosuppressive antibody directed against this receptor and has similar indications. Common adverse effects seen with these medications include hypercholesterolemia, electrolyte disturbances, and hypertension. Serious reactions include immunosuppression, infection, opportunistic infections, malignancy, thrombocytopenia, and diabetes mellitus.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition By Bertram G. Katzung

questions.text: Which of the following does not affect the resolving power of a microscope?
questions.solution:
In a microscope, the resolution depends upon wavelength and numerical aperture, which in turn is influenced by refractive index and angular aperture.

Resolving power of microscope:

  • Resolving power denotes the smallest detail that a microscope can resolve when imaging a specimen; it is a function of the design of the instrument and the properties of the light used in image formation.
  • The smaller the distance between the two points that can be distinguished, the higher the resolving power.
  • Thus, according to the formula d = 0.61 λ / NA, the resolving power can be increased in two ways:
    • decreasing the wavelength, λ (ie by using filters)
    • increasing the NA (numerical apertures). As stated earlier, NA = n sinu.
  • Thus, NA can be increased the following ways:
    • increasing the refraction index, n (this can be done by adding oil to the object)
    • increasing the angle of light coming from the object, u

Reference: Apurba Shastry, 2nd edition

questions.text:
60-year-old man presents with colicky abdominal pain and foul-smelling watery diarrhea. Current medications include intravenous ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin for CAP for 6 days. A PCR test is positive for C. difficile toxins. Oral treatment with vancomycin is started. Which of the following sentences are correct regarding the newly initiated treatment?
1. It can cause red man syndrome, which can be prevented by slowing the rate of infusion and pretreating with antihistamines.
2. In contrast to amino-glycosides, ototoxicity and vestibular toxicity are more for vancomycin.
3. It can cause systemic side effects such as nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity and DRESS syndrome.
4. Patients may be affected predominantly by dysgeusia and gastrointestinal side effects.
questions.solution:
As per given clinical scenario, a patient has C.difficile infection after long term antibiotic therapy.

Vancomycin and fidaxomicin are the preferred antibiotic agents for treating CDI. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, measures to prevent transmission (e.g., patient cohorting or isolation, strict adherence to hygiene measures) should be followed, especially in hospitals and other health care settings.

Antibiotic therapy for C. difficile infection in adults -

  • Initial episode
    • Nonsevere CDI or severe CDI
      • First-line - Oral fidaxomicin OR oral vancomycin
      • Second-line for nonsevere cases (if vancomycin and fidaxomicin are unavailable or inappropriate, e.g., in patients with allergies): oral metronidazole
    • Fulminant CDI
      • First-line: high-dose oral vancomycin
      • Consider adding IV metronidazole
      • In patients with paralytic ileus, consider adding vancomycin enemas.
  • Recurrent CDI
    • First recurrence
      • If the initial episode was treated with standard-dose vancomycin:Oral fidaxomicin [OR tapered and pulsed oral vancomycin
      • If the initial episode was treated with metronidazole: Oral fidaxomicin OR standard-dose oral vancomycin
    • Subsequent recurrences -

Any of the following:

  • Oral fidaxomicin
  • Standard-dose oral vancomycin followed by oral rifaximin
  • Tapered and pulsed oral vancomycin

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition By Bertram G. Katzung Pg no. 802

questions.text: A researcher wishes to study the effect of an antimicrobial that inhibits peptidoglycan synthesis of bacteria. In which phase of the growth curve should he observe the maximum effect of the antimicrobial?
questions.solution:
• Lag phase:
    • Vigorous metabolic activity occurs but cells do not divide
    • Few minutes up to many hours
  • Log (logarithmic/Exponential) phase
    • Rapid cell division occurs
    • Lactam drugs act during this phase when cells are making peptidoglycan 3
  • Stationary phase
    • Nutrient depletion or toxic products
    • Growth slows till number of new cells produced = the number of cells that die
  • Death phase
    • Decline in the number of viable bacteria

Reference: Apurba Shastry, 2nd edition

questions.text: A 56-year-old man complaints of shortness of breath when going for walk. An echocardiography shows an ejection fraction of 30% (normal > 55%). Laboratory studies show a fasting blood glucose level of 248 mg/dL and creatinine of 1.6 mg/dL. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of a drug that is contraindicated for use in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Thiazolidinediones, such as pioglitazone and rosiglitazone, are antidiabetic agents that increase insulin sensitivity through by binding to peroxisome proliferator activated receptors (PAR) in target tissues for insulin action such as skeletal muscle, adipose tissue and the liver.
  • The activation of PPAR-gamma receptors regulates the transcription of insulin-responsive genes that are involved in the control of glucose production, transport, and utilization. This results in enhanced tissue sensitivity to insulin.
  • As a drug class, the thiazolidinediones are contraindicated for use in patients with NYHA Class Ill or IV heart failure because of worsening heart failure symptoms, fluid retention leading to peripheral edema, and the promotion of weight gain.
  • This patient has Class 3 heart failure in which he has fatigue and dyspnea on routine activity and cause marked limitation of physical activity.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition By Bertram G. Katzung, Pg no. 758

questions.text: Prions are best removed by:
questions.solution:
• Prions are the most resistant structure to sterilization and disinfection.
  • Prions can be sterilized by either steam sterilization or using a combination of sodium hydroxide and autoclaving, using 1 of the 4 following options:
    • Autoclave at 134°C for 18 minutes in a prevacuum sterilizer.
    • Autoclave at 132°C for 1 hour in a gravity displacement sterilizer.
    • Immerse in 1 N NaOH (1 N NaOH is a solution of 40 g NaOH in 1 L water) for 1 hour; remove and rinse in water, then transfer to an open pan and autoclave (121°C gravity displacement sterilizer or 134°C porous prevacuum sterilizer) for 1 hour.
    • Immerse in 1 N NaOH for 1 hour and heat in a gravity displacement sterilizer at 121°C for 30 minutes, then clean and subject to routine sterilization.
  • However, it remains unclear which of the above options is best for completely eradicating prions from medical equipment.

Reference: Apurba Shastry, 2nd edition

In the USA, zileuton is approved for use in an oral dosage of 1200 mg of the sustained-release form twice daily; zafirlukast, 20 mg twice daily; and montelukast, 10 mg (for adults) or 4 mg (for children) once daily.

questions.text: The test (shown in the picture) is used in central sterile supply departments (CSSD). What is the most appropriate interpretation of a complete color change in the test?
questions.solution:
This is a Bowie-Dick test to assess adequate working of the instrument sterilization procedures.

  • The most common sterilization method for medical instruments is moist heat, i.e. pressurized steam.
  • The Bowie-Dick test is a heat-detecting color change sheet inserted into the middle of a block of absorbent paper sheets, wrapped in paper and put in the sterilizer.
  • The center of the sheet should change color in the same way as the edges of the sheet. This means that steam has penetrated to the center of the pack, and hence penetrated the center of instrument packs too.
  • Lack of uniform color change results in test failure.

Reference: Apurba Shastry, 2nd edition

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is presented with periorbital edema, a maculopapular rash on her chest, and a fever of 101F. She has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. Laboratory studies of serum show: Sodium = 139 mEq/L, Potassium = 4.8 mEq/L, Chloride = 100 mEg/L, Bicarbonate = 24 mEq/L, BUN =58 mg/dL and Creatinine = 3.1 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows mild proteinuria and eosinophils. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for the findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) is caused by an acute inflammation of the renal interstitium and is most likely related to a hypersensitivity reaction. This condition is usually caused by a drug.
  • Examples of drugs producing this condition include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen and indomethacin; antibiotics such as penicillins, cephalosporins, and sulfonamides; diuretics such as furosemide and thiazides; and other drugs such as phenytoin, cimetidine, allopurinol, and proton pump inhibitors.
  • The typical presentation for acute interstitial nephritis is the development of oliguria, fever, and rash that starts days to weeks after starting the drug. Eosinophils are seen in the urine. This can progress to renal papillary necrosis. Treatment consists primarily of supportive measures and removal of the inciting agent, as well as corticosteroids, such as prednisone
  • In addition to acute interstitial nephritis, NSAIDs can also produce hemodynamically-mediated renal failure because of the reduction of prostaglandin synthesis. Renal prostaglandins cause vasodilation. Normally, they do not have much influence on renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate, so in a healthy individual, NSAIDs likely have minimal effect on renal function.
  • However, in edematous or volume-depleted states, these prostaglandins compensate for angiotensin- or epinephrine-induced renal vasoconstriction. The blockade of prostaglandin production by NSAIDs in these conditions, can lead to unopposed vasoconstriction and acute renal failure. Risk factors include diabetes, heart failure, cirrhosis, dehydration, blood or fluid loss, and being elderly.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition By Bertram G. Katzung, Pg no. 260

questions.text:
A 20 year old female presents to the OPD with a 1 week history of fever, hepatosplenomegaly and classical pink spots on her trunk which fade with pressure. The physician observed that despite having fever, the patient exhibited bradycardia and prompted his intern to collect the patient's blood for bacterial culture. On blood culture, a bacteria producing black colonies as shown in the image was isolated. What other selective media can be used for identification of this bacteria?

1. DCA agar
2. Stuart's media
3. CIN agar
4. Hektoen Enteric agar
5. Selenite F broth
6. XLD agar
questions.solution:
• The above clinical vignette and black coloured growth (due to H2S) on Wilson Blair Bismuth Sulphite medium points towards the diagnosis of Salmonella typhi infection. It is commonly diagnosed by blood culture in 1st week of Salmonella can be transported in Cary Blair media.
  • Selective media for its isolation include, DCA, XLD, Hekton Enteric Agar, Salmonella Shigella Agar and Wilson Blair Bismuth Sulphite medium.
  • It can also be grown on Selenite F broth, which is an ENRICHMENT media.

However, the above question specifically asks for selective media and hence, e) is not included in the answer here.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 404

questions.text: Which is the only shigella species which does not test positive for the following biochemical reaction?
questions.solution:
The given biochemical reaction is the catalase reaction. This enzyme detoxifies hydrogen peroxide by breaking it down into water and oxygen gas. The bubbles resulting from production of oxygen gas clearly indicate a catalase positive result.

All shigella are catalase positive except shigella dysenteriae type 1.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, byApurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 400

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with severe hypertriglyceridemia is on fibrate medication in the past but could not tolerate it due to liver toxicity. The physician prescribes the appropriate medications and explains that the patient is likely to experience skin flushing and warmth after taking the pills. Which of the following is the primary agent mediating these side effects?
questions.solution:
Nicotinic acid, or niacin, has been used in the treatment of hyperlipidemia for almost 4 decades. It is effective in raising HDL cholesterol levels, as well as lowering triglycerides and LDL levels.

Niacin's main side effects are cutaneous flushing, warmth, and itching; these are primarily mediated by release of prostaglandins (particularly PGD2and PGE2).

Aspirin, which inhibits prostaglandin synthesis, can significantly reduce these side effects if given 30-60 minutes before niacin administration. The side effects are also reduced with slow-release preparations or if niacin is taken with meals. They are worst when niacin is first initiated and tend to fade over time due to tachyphylaxis.

Reference:- Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition By Bertram G. Katzung, Pg no. 221

questions.text:
Choose the most appropriate option regarding whether the following statements are true or false.
1.Non-venereal treponematosis also produces genital cutaneous manifestation.
2.Syphilis can be transmitted through both venereal and non venereal mode.
3.The antigenic structure of venereal and non venereal treponematosis is different.
4.T.pertenue is an example of non venereal treponematosis.
questions.solution:
Treponemesare slender spirochetes with fine spirals having pointed ends. Most of them are commensals in mouth and genitalia. Only a few species are pathogenic to men, which can be divided into two groups -

  • Sexually-transmitted: Treponema pallidum-it causes syphilis, can be transmitted by both venereal and non venereal mode.
  • Nonvenerealtreponematoses: T. pertenue, T. endemicum and T. carateum.

They are almost identical with T. pallidum in their morphology, antigenic structure and in genetic composition.

However, they differ from T. pallidum, being transmitted by non-sexual mode (by direct contact) and produce non-genital cutaneous manifestations.

Reference:- Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 757

questions.text: Assertion: Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) promotes water reabsorption in the collecting ducts of the kidney. Reasoning: ADH increases the number of aquaporin channels in the apical membrane of the collecting duct cells, which allows for water to be reabsorbed into the bloodstream
questions.solution:
Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, is a hormone that helps to regulate the body's water balance by promoting water reabsorption in the kidneys. The assertion that ADH promotes water reabsorption in the collecting ducts of the kidney is true. The reasoning that ADH increases the number of aquaporin channels in the apical membrane of the collecting duct cells, which allows for water to be reabsorbed into the bloodstream, is also true and is the correct explanation of the assertion. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

Reference:- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, page 31

questions.text: Lesion at which of the following nuclei will cause hypothalamic obesity
questions.solution:
Food intake is primarily controlled by hypothalamic centers. There are two established groups of hypothalamic nuclei that influence feeding, the lateral hypothalamus (LH)known as feeding center and the ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH)known as satiety center. So lesion in the ventromedial nucleus leads to hypothalamic obesity.

questions.text:
Which of the following receptor(s) has/have phagocytic properties?
i Scavenger receptors
ii Mechanoreceptors
iii Mannose receptors
iv Chemoreceptors
questions.solution:
Phagocytosis involves three sequential steps:

  • Recognition and attachment of the particle to be ingested by the leukocyte;
  • Engulfment, with subsequent formation of a phagocytic vacuole;
  • Killing or degradation of the ingested material.

These steps are triggered by activation of phagocytes by microbes, necrotic debris, and various mediators. Mannose receptors, scavenger receptors, and receptors for various opsonins bind and ingest microbes.

Reference:-Robbins And Cotran Pathologic Basis Of Disease, 10th ed Pg:6

questions.text: ATP as a neurotransmitter acts on which receptors?
questions.solution:
It has recently been identified as a neurotransmitter. ATP binds to P2X receptors, which are ligand-gated ion channel receptors. P2X receptors have widespread distributions throughout the body, including the dorsal horn, which implicates a role for ATP in sensory transmission. Antagonists of P2X receptors are under development for the treatment of chronic pain. ATP also binds to P2Y and P2U receptors, which are GPCR.

Reference:- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition Page 420

questions.text:
What is/are true about metastatic calcification in the following sentences?
i Calcification starts in mitochondria.
ii Occurs in damaged heart valves.
iii Serum calcium level is normal
iv Occurs in dead/dying tissue
questions.solution:
Metastatic calcification. This form is associated with hypercalcemia and can occur in normal tissues. The major causes of hypercalcemia are -

  • increased secretion of parathyroid hormone, due to either primary parathyroid tumors or production of parathyroid hormone-related protein by other malignant tumors;
  • destruction of bone due to the effects of accelerated turnover (e.g., Paget disease), immobilization, or tumors (increased bone catabolism associated with multiple myeloma, leukemia, or diffuse skeletal metastases);
  • vitamin D-related disorders including vitamin D intoxication and sarcoidosis (in which macrophages activate a vitamin D precursor); and
  • renal failure, in which phosphate retention leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Reference:-Robbins And Cotran Pathologic Basis Of Disease, 10th ed Pg:53
