questions.text:
Assertion (A): Rh incompatibility between the mother and the fetus can lead to hemolytic disease of the newborn.
Reasoning (R): Rh incompatibility occurs when a Rh-positive mother carries a Rh-negative fetus and develops antibodies against the fetal Rh antigens.
questions.solution:
• In HDN, the mother is Rh-negative while the fetus is Rh-positive.
  • It occurs when the mother's immune system produces antibodies that attack and destroy red cells of the fetus.
  • Symptoms of HDN include anemia, jaundice, enlarged liver and spleen.
  • Treatment of HDN may include phototherapy to treat jaundice, blood transfusions to replace the destroyed RBCs, and exchange transfusions to remove the mother's antibody from the baby's bloodstream.
  • Prevention of HDN involves administering Rh immune globulin to Rh-negative mothers during pregnancy and after delivery.

Reference:-Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition,Pg. 471-475

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with anemia, jaundice, and severe fatigue. Physical examination reveals a small head circumference, a prominent forehead, and enlarged spleen. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows an elevated level of fetal hemoglobin (HbF). A complete blood count shows a low mean corpuscular volume (MCV), low mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH), and low mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Elevated HbF is also characteristic of beta-thalassemia.
  • Beta thalassemia is a genetic disorder that affects the production of Hb, the proteins in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body. Individuals with beta thalassemia produce less beta globulin, a component of hemoglobin, than normal. This leads to a shortage of red blood cells and a decrease in the amount that can be carried by the blood.
  • All the findings which are mentioned in the child are indicative of the disorder beta thalassemia.

Reference:-Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Edition. Pg. 439-447

questions.text: A 6-month old girl presenting with anemia is tested positive for ALAS 2 gene mutation, and diagnosed with hereditary sideroblastic anemia. An image of her peripheral smear is shown below. Identify the inclusion body shown.
questions.solution:
This is the dimorphic blood picture typical of sideroblasticanemia. Anisocytosis is present with microcytes, macrocytes, and normocytes. Numerous inclusions (Pappen heimer bodies) (iron deposits) are also seen.

questions.text: A 65 year old lady presented after a road traffic accident. She has injured her inferior frontal gyrus. What will be the outcome with respect to her language skills?
questions.solution:
Aphasias are abnormalities of language functions and are caused by lesions in the categorical hemisphere. They are classified as fluent (Wernickearea), nonfluent (Brocaarea), and anomic (angular gyrus) based on the location of brain lesions.

questions.text:
A patient with Hirschsprung disease is brought to the hospital for treatment. Which of the following is true about the enteric nervous system in Hirschsprung disease?
I. There is an absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric and submucosal plexus
II. There is increased motility in the affected segment
III. Parasympathetic stimulation of the affected segment can restore normal motility
IV. Ganglion cells are present in the affected segment, but they are unable to function.
questions.solution:
Hirschsprung disease is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric and submucosal plexus, leading to decreased motility in the affected segment.

Parasympathetic stimulation is not effective in restoring normal motility, as the ganglion cells are absent.

Reference:-Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, page 836.

questions.text: When are the fingerprint patterns determined?
questions.solution:
• Fingerprint patterns are determined by the 4th month of gestation and remain fixed throughout life.
  • Fingerprints are impressions of patterns that are formed by papillary or epidermal ridges at the fingertips. They begin to appear between 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life. The formation is completed by 24 weeks. At birth, a fine pattern of ridges is seen on the skin of the bulbs of the fingers and thumbs, parts of the palms, and the soles of the feet.

Reference: Encyclopedia of Forensic and Legal medicine Page No 1, Volume 3
